page.title: 12Farming (6)
page.content: There has always been tension between farmers and public, especially with regard to conservation and footpaths, but both sides are becoming more aware and tolerant of the other's needs. Nevertheless farmlands such as these tend to be very private places. The farmhouses are mainly tucked away, and drivers passing through have very few glimpses of the farmer or farmhand at work, and little contact with them. All farmers questioned were interested and helpful. There are no problems from stubble burning and little from vandalism, apart from slight damage from the local hunt or gates left open but broiler-house owners fear animal- rights protesters, and gypsies wanting land might be a problem. Bee-keepers report good relations with farmers, who advise them of spraying times so hives can be closed when necessary.
